description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description: It was announced on May 17, 2020, that the Estonia Government approved easing of restrictions in force after the end of the emergency situation. Starting from May 19, 2020, Education in lower secondary schools, upper secondary schools, vocational education institutions and higher education institutions (except in research and development institutions of universities and research institutions), as well as in continuous education institutions, informal education, and hobby activities, and the activities of open youth centers must follow the 2+2 rule; students may work in groups of no more than 10 students (except for exams); when organising the exams the students must be dispersed in the exam room, the movement of groups of students must be dispersed, and all items in common use must be disinfected after use.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported

institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions

description:
July 1, 2020. Estonia Government allows all basic schools, upper secondary schools, vocational educational institutions and institutions of higher education, to organise public events if the following requirements are met:  
1) The organiser of an event ensures the scattering of people
2) The organiser of an indoor event ensures up to 50% attendance capacity but no more than 1500 people

description:
On April 2 2020, the Estonian government approved the amendments to the Aliens Act and the Obligation to Leave and Prohibition on Entry Act with the aim of ensuring that foreigners from third countries who have lost their jobs leave Estonia at the earliest possibility. In such cases, the Police and Border Guard Board can annul a foreigner's visa or visa-free period and issue a precept ordering them to leave Estonia. 

In case a foreigner's visa or visa-free period expires but they are temporarily unable to leave Estonia due to the movement restrictions imposed under the emergency situation, according to the draft, the Minister of the Interior or the Director General of the Police and Border Guard Board can grant them grounds for remaining in Estonia until the end of the emergency situation.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: 21st April 2020, an amendment to the Aliens Act has passed through the Riigikogu and has been entered into law by the Estonian Parliament.  The amendment requires non-EU foreigners with expired short-term work permits to depart Estonia as soon as possible.  This amendment does not impact individuals holding temporary residence permits.  If current emergency border closures prevent departure, impacted individuals may temporarily remain in Estonia but must depart within 10 days of the emergency situation being lifted.  Agricultural workers on short-term work permits will be granted the option of extending their work permit until July 31st, 2020.

description: From 1st July 2020, the Estonian government advises against travel abroad. Traveling for tourism is not safe and is discouraged. If the trip is urgent, consider the following  Before going abroad get to know the conditions for entering the country of destination  find out whether you will be allowed into the country. If in doubt, contact the Border Guard of the destination country. If you have to go through any other countries to reach your destination, find out the transit rules of those countries as well. It is not possible to use the special flights that are bringing Estonian residents home for travelling abroad. Take into account that in order to limit the spread of the corona virus, the states can unexpectedly restrict the conditions for entering their country and moving around there. You can get stuck in quarantine abroad and getting home could be very complicated, sometimes impossible.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
From 6th of July 2020, Estonia is opening its borders to low-infection countries outside the European Union, based on the recommendation given by the Council of the European Union. The list of these countries will be updated every two weeks. This means that the borders remain closed for travellers from countries not included in this list or countries not members of the European Union, Schengen or the United Kingdom.

Additionally, the borders will open to travellers from all countries who are coming to Estonia with the purpose of work or study. However, these travellers may be subject to self-isolation.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
From 1st June 2020, Estonia is opening its borders for travellers from European Union and Schengen countries as well as from the United Kingdom. This means that Estonia is now reopening its borders for the European free-movement area after closing its borders on the 17th of March 2020. Estonian borders remain closed for countries outside the regional block. UPDATE: The original policy states that Estonia keeps its borders closed for all countries outside the European Union, Schengen and the United Kingdom, The government is now, 6th July, 2020, opening the borders to "low-infection" countries outside the European Union, which was recommended by the Council of the European Union. Further, the list of third countries from which entry into Estonia is permitted will be updated every two weeks and published on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Additionally, from 6th July 2020, all travellers without symptoms with the purpose of coming to work or study in Estonia are allowed to enter the country, although condition of mandatory self-isolation might apply.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Estonia has launched a new Digital Nomad Visa  on 1st august 2020, that allows remote workers to live in Estonia and legally work for their employer or their own company registered abroad. The following may apply  persons who are able to work remotely; persons can perform their work duties remotely using telecommunications technology; persons who either have an active employment contract with a company registered outside of Estonia, conduct business thorugh their own company registered abroad, or work as a freelancer for clients mostly outside of Estonia; and, they can provide evidence that their income met the minimum threshold during the six months preceding the application. Currently, the monthly income threshold is    3504  gross of tax . This is currently only open to countries which the EU deems safe for interregional travel.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From 14th August 2020, travel to Estonia is possible for the following  citizens and residents of the EU, Schengen area, the United Kingdom, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Vatican City, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay and individuals with long-stay visas and their family members if they show no symptoms.

description: On 28 August 2020, Estonian government members approved a conceptual decision to continue with the current air travel restrictions for countries where the COVID-19 infection rate has been 25 or higher per 100,000 people in the last 14 days. Exceptions for these include Frankfurt, Helsinki, Copenhagen, London, Riga, and Warsaw. These cities are open for travelling from the Tallinn Airport regardless of the prevalence rates. Acceptable destinations are also countries where the prevalence rate per 100,000 people remains under 25 people.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Frankfurt, Helsinki, Copenhagen, London, Riga and Warsaw

description: From, 1st September 2020, in the event of a negative COVID-19 test result, it will be possible to go to work after coming from countries at risk if this is absolutely necessary and a negative virus test is given immediately upon arrival in the country. A second test must be performed no earlier than 7 days after the result of the first test, and if it is negative, normal life can be resumed. This means that a person will not be subjected to 14-day self-isolation after two negative tests, which applies to all those coming from high-risk countries who do not take the test.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported

description: The Estonian government decided to relax its regulations concerning restrictions on direct passenger air travel between Estonia and other European Countries. From 5th October 2020, direct passenger connections with Estonia are allowed if the country's infection rate is lower than the European average per 100 000 inhabitants in the last 14 days. The list of these countries is updated every Friday.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
As the emergency situation comes to end at midnight 18 May 2020, the government of Estonia signed an order on the 17th of May 2020 restricting passenger air travel between Estonia and countries with infection rate higher than 25 per 100 000 inhabitants in the last two weeks. This restriction is based on the mutual travel bubble established by the Baltic countries. The Ministry of Economic Affairs and Communications is regularly reviewing the reopening of air routes based on the agreed-upon restriction. 
 UPDATE: The original flight ban included flight to and from countries with rate of infection higher 25 per 100 000 inhabitants in the last 14 days. The update states easing of this restriction so that now the flight ban only applies to countries which have infection rate higher than the European Union average.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Estonian Ministry of Health, together with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, has announced that starting from April 26, if a student was abroad during school holidays, he is subject to a 10-day self-isolation period or two PCR tests for coronavirus at least six days apart. The first test can be taken in a foreign country no later than 72 hours before arrival in Estonia or immediately after entering Estonia. Students and youth can only return to school and clubs after a second negative test result. There are some countries that are not subject to the ''''''' self-isolation obligation, a list of which is available on the website of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. When entering Estonia, you must fill out a border crossing declaration.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: before arriving in estonia, you must fill out a traveller's questionnaire. the questionnaire can be completed within three days of your arrival in estonia. this makes border-crossing smoother and you can avoid queueing for filling out the questionnaire on paper. the border guard or airline can ask people crossing the border to present an electronic or printed border crossing confirmation sent via email. those individuals who have already had covid-19 or who have been vaccinated, or any other individuals who are not subject to restrictions on their freedom of movement pursuant to the respective order by the government of the republic of estonia are not required to submit the declaration if they are able to provide proof of the grounds for their exemption.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description: The Baltic country of Estonia has imposed stricter entry restrictions on arrivals from Spain. Starting from, July 12, "travellers from Spain are being quarantined in Estonia due to the increase in the number of COVID-19 cases in Spain." There is a ten-day restriction of freedom of movement after arrival in Estonia. That may be shortened by performing "a coronavirus PCR test abroad, up to 72 hours before arrival in Estonia. While in Estonia, it is then possible to take a second test not earlier than on the sixth day after the first test taken abroad. A person is released from the ten-day isolation obligation ahead of time if the results of both tests are negative."
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting March 1, a special Covid-19 Estonian Health Board will contact those who may have been in close contact with the sick person and advise them to limit their social contacts. description: On March 1, the Estonian Ministry of Health published precautionary measures to combat covid-19: If you have mild symptoms of a respiratory illness, carefully follow the usual rules of hand hygiene and stay at home until you recover. If you have a fever, cough, and difficulty breathing, get help early. Take care of your health and stay at home. Call your general practitioner. If you do not have access to a GP, call the GP hotline on 1220.

description: Starting March 19, 2020, the Estonian government has decided that health care professionals with the right to prescribe medicinal products are allowed to prescribe medicinal products for chronic diseases for no more than two months at a time.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting March 19, 2020, the Estonian government imposed restrictions on how pharmacies are allowed to dispense medicinal products. For repeat prescriptions, pharmacies may only dispense one prescription at a time and the prescription should cover no more than the customer's needs two months into the future. For over-the-counter medicinal products, no more than two packagings per proprietary medicinal product and per one customer are allowed. Pharmacies should only dispense medicinal products if the medicinal products already purchased do not suffice for the next two months of treatment or until the end of treatment, or if the life or health of a person would be compromised by non-dispensing of a medicinal product.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On 16 April 2020, the government decided to support two sero-epidemiological studies in Estonia to determine the extent of the spread of coronavirus in the country. Testing will be carried out under the research project of the COVID-19 monitoring system and will be carried out by the research team of the University of Tartu. People will be selected based on random selection for testing across Estonia. description: The Health Board recommends disinfecting the door handles, handrails, elevator buttons etc. of apartment buildings at least once a day. Viruses are destroyed by a disinfectant that contains at least 70  ethanol. Hallways have to be cleaned with water and water-absorbent cloth because cleaning dust with a dry brush will not get rid of the virus. When cleaning it is important to use disposable gloves and easy-to-clean working clothes and footwear in order to protect yourself from chemical cleaning agents and contamination on surfaces. If possible, the apartment associations could provide hand-sanitisers near entrances and lifts. You should, however, definitely remember to wash your hands thoroughly after coming home.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: At the briefing on May 12, MoH of Estonia again reminded that It is still always important to guarantee adequate air exchange in rooms to reduce the amount of virus particles in the rooms of both sick and healthy people. For this we recommend To air your living spaces regularly In public spaces, to guarantee a good round-the-clock air exchange that would not allow the virus particles and contaminants to accumulate.In non-residential premises and social welfare institutions, the ventilation system must not be switched off even if the building is not in use. The ventilation system must also operate at evenings and weekends at with either design capacity or normal daily regime 100 or reduced capacity at least 40 . The ventilation system operating with reduced capacity must be switched to the design capacity regime at least two hours before the building or part of the building will be used. Circulating air ventilation systems are in use in storehouses and shopping centres. They must be fully switched onto the external air injection to avoid possible virus circulation through the ventilation system. In other ventilation systems, the air injection and extraction settings must be reviewed so that the system sends the air exhaust out without recirculating it. If the building does not have an air conditioning and ventilation system that guarantees suitable indoor climate, the rooms must be actively aired. This should be done at least once an hour and within 15 minutes before people ar
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Both the Health Board (Terviseamet) and the government agree that wearing face masks in public in an effort to curb the spread of the coronavirus need not be made mandatory. The authorities say research on the use of masks has been controversial, and that wearing them incorrectly can do more harm than good.10.08.20They are recommended for those who have contracted the virus who have to leave home for unavoidable reasons, and those who have been in close contact with a carrier, or in enclosed, crowded public spaces like public transport."The Health Board and the government are of the opinion that face masks should not be mandatory in Estonia, but should remain only recommended for patients in situations where leaving home, or close contact with someone with the virus, is unavoidable," Hanna Sepp, chief specialist at the board said.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Following the amendments made on the restrictions of movement between the Estonian western islands and the mainland, from 16th March 2020, the movement between the mainland and the islands of Hiiumaa, Kihnu, Muhu, Ruhnu, Saarema, Vormsi and Manija is suspended. Only residents are allowed to access the islands but not allowed to travel to the mainland. However, following the amendment, residents of the islands are allowed to return to their jobs in the mainland and vice versa, but cannot return home until their quarantine period is over.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries
target_city: Hiiumaa; Kihnu; Muhu;, Ruhnu; Saarema; Vormsi; Manija

description: Following the easing of restrictions on the Estonian western islands, from 28th April 2020, the restrictions on freedom of movement between the islands of  Hiiumaa, Kihnu, Muhu, Ruhnu, Saarema, Vormsi and Manija stay in place. Only residents of the islands are allowed to travel to islands. However, people with granted special permits are allowed one return trip to the islands. Following breakdown of permits per day applies: 25 permits for Saaremaa, 5 permits for Muhu, 20 permits for Hiiumaa, and 10 permits for Kihnu, Ruhnu and Vormsi each. Additionally, residents of the islands are allowed to return to their jobs to the mainland but cannot return home until the quarantine period is over.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: After a positive case of covid inside, a student dormitory at University of Tartu is placed in lockdown 17th April 2020.  All the residents must remain at their apartments until they have received the results of their COVID-19 test and until all the people who have been in close contact with the infected persons have been identified, and the test results have been returned. Students who have tested positive for the virus, must remain in self-isolation until recovery. People who have been in close contact with the infected persons and who have tested negative for COVID-19, will nevertheless need to stay at their apartments in the dorm for two weeks and monitor their health status.

description:
Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 â As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders during the e-sessions of the Government. 
First, the Government approved the order to continue to restrict the sale of alcohol at all places selling alcohol, including restaurants and bars, from 22:00 to 10:00. The restrictions do not apply on board of a ship or an aircraft used for international passenger transport and to a sales premises located in the security area of the international airport or port. The restriction on the sale of alcohol applies to catering establishments, including bars and other similar sales premises until July 1.

description: Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 When visiting museums and exhibition institutions, the 2+2 rule must be observed; for visiting groups, there may be a maximum of ten visitors in the group; the availability of disinfectants must be ensured. description:
Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 â As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18, the Government approved four orders during the e-sessions of the Government yesterday, confirming restrictions and easing of restrictions in force after the end of the emergency situation.
Until June 30, all public events are prohibited.
As an exception, public events are allowed in the open air, where visitors are in their cars, such as drive-in cinemas and concerts. The organiser of the event must ensure that the 2+2 rule is observed, the participants must not leave the car without an unavoidable reason and the distance between parked cars must remain sufficient. If necessary, the organiser of the event must ensure the provision of disinfectants on the spot.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: Allowance of some public events in the open air

description: Tallinn, Stenbock House, 11 June 2020 â The government clarified its previous order and provided that a person arriving in Estonia from a country with a higher COVID-19 infection rate would be subject to a 14-day restriction on freedom of movement. Quarantine was previously required, but for the sake of legal clarity, the wording of the order was clarified by adding a restriction on freedom of movement.Similarly to the current regulation, the specified order stipulates that the restriction of freedom of movement is applied during the latent period of infection, or 14 days. This means a prohibition on leaving the place of residence or permanent residence, except on the instructions of a healthcare professional or a police officer or in the event of an emergency endangering a personâs life or health. People can also leave home to receive healthcare services or if it is not possible to obtain food, basic necessities, or medicine in any other way.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_text: The restriction on freedom of movement after crossing state borders
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Tallinn, Stenbock House, 18 June 2020 â As of 19 June, the government has decided to replace the 2+2 rule with a requirement for people to disperse. This means that a safe distance between people must continue to be maintained, but the state no longer requires compliance with the 2+2 rule.Dispersion requirements will replace the 2+2 rule in all public spaces, such as stores, service points and public-use spaces at shopping centres, as well as at casinos and slot machine locations. In place of the 2+2 rule, dispersion must also be ensured at public events, public meetings and religious services.The requirement will apply to public saunas, spas, swimming pools and water parks, as well as bowling, billiards and children's playrooms. Along with the organisation of activities in basic schools, upper secondary schools, vocational schools and institutes of higher education, training centres, hobby schools, recreational activity providers, and public youth centres. It will also be in place at children's and student camps, sports and museum and exhibition visits.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: Social distancing of 2 meters is replaced by dispersing.

description: Tallinn, Stenbock House, 28 August 2020 â Government members approved a conceptual decision to continue with the current air travel restrictions for countries where the COVID-19 infection rate has been 25 or higher per 100,000 people in the last 14 days. Exceptions to these restrictions were established for scheduled flights to the following destinations: Frankfurt, Helsinki, Copenhagen, London, Riga, and Warsaw. These cities are open for travelling from the Tallinn Airport regardless of the prevalence rates. Acceptable destinations are also countries where the prevalence rate per 100,000 people remains under 25 people.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Republic of EstoniaMinistry of Foreign AffairsStarting from 1 September, people with a negative COVID-19 test arriving from countries with an increased risk of infection (with an infection rate exceeding 16 and marked as red or countries not included in the following list https://vm.ee/en/information-countries-and-self-isolation-requirements-p...) are permitted to go to work if it is absolutely crucial, and on the condition that they immediately test negative for the virus on their arrival. All contact with other people must be avoided while waiting for the test results. In case of a negative test result, the restriction on the freedom of movement applies for the first seven days, i.e. it is allowed to go to work or shop for essentials in case of emergencies but non-essential contacts should be avoided. They must take a second test no earlier than 7 days after the first test and if the test is also negative, they are free to continue their everyday life. This means that the 14-day restriction on the freedom of movement does not apply to them after two negative tests.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Essential workers (please note their occuption in the text entry where applicable)

description: 12.08.2020 17:23LikeA class in progress at Pelgulinn high school in pre-pandemic days.A class in progress at Pelgulinn high school in pre-pandemic days. Source: ERRThe Ministry of Education has said that guidelines it is providing to schools ahead of the academic year starting on September 1 are just that, and not mandatory responsibilities, adding that these have taken on board lessons learned during the spring coronavirus peak and are aimed at avoiding a return to remote learning.Estonian schools have not had in-classroom teaching since March, due to the pandemic. After some discussion about schools returning early, in mid-August, for the 2020-2021 academic year, the decision was made to stick to the traditional September 1 first day of school.

description: Estonia and Singapore are co-sponsoring a Global Declaration on the Digital Response to COVID-19, âClose the Digital Divides: the Digital Response to COVID-19â. description: After a positive case of covid inside, a student dormitory at University of Tartu is placed in lockdown 17th April 2020. All the residents must remain at their apartments until they have received the results of their COVID-19 test and until all the people who have been in close contact with the infected persons have been identified, and the test results have been returned. Students who have tested positive for the virus, must remain in self-isolation until recovery. People who have been in close contact with the infected persons and who have tested negative for COVID-19, will nevertheless need to stay at their apartments in the dorm for two weeks and monitor their health status.

description: The Government approved an order extending the restrictions on crossing the Estonian state border and 14-day quarantine requirement for persons who had previously been subject to this requirement. From 18th May 2020, Latvian or Lithuanian citizens, holders of residence permits, or persons with a right of residence in these countries who have no symptoms of the disease, may enter Estonia without an obligation for quarantine. Additionally, Finnish citizens, holders of residence permits or persons with a right of residence in Finland, who have no symptoms of the disease, who come to Estonia to work, study or for unavoidable family reasons such as meeting with their close relatives, attending a funeral or a wedding, or need to visit due to a case of illness, can also enter Estonia. People without symptoms of the disease, who have had the right to enter Estonia previously without an obligation to stay in quarantine, may continue to do so. For example, people transporting goods and raw materials, persons involved in the international carriage of cargo and passengers, persons involved in the technical work of a company operating in Estonia, health care providers, diplomats, people arriving within the framework of international military cooperation, etc.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description:
Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 â As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18 2020, the Estonian Government approved four orders. 
Secondly, the Government confirmed the order to establish quarantine after the end of the emergency situation for COVID-19 patients and people living with them who are in close contact with the patients.
People infected with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence from the time of diagnosis until recovery. This also applies to the people using shelters and other such services who must remain in quarantine at their place of stay.

People in close contact with infected persons may move outside their residence to a limited extent only if they have no symptoms of the disease.  It is allowed to leave the home if it is unavoidable, and for spending some time outdoors, if all the measures are taken to prevent the spread of the disease, and instructions of the Health Board are observed.

The person may also leave their residence if they have received an order from a health care worker or a police officer instructing them to leave the place of residence or permanent stay, or in the event of an emergency which threatens the person's life or health.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: People with certain health conditions (please note which health conditions in the text entry),Other population not specifed above

description:
Tallinn, Stenbock House, May 17, 2020 â As the emergency situation comes to an end at midnight of May 18 2020, the Government approved four orders. 
- extending the restrictions on crossing the Estonian state border. 

-extending the restrictions  on crossing the Estonian state border and 14-day quarantine requirement for persons who had previously been subject to this requirement.

-Latvian or Lithuanian citizens, holders of residence permits, or persons with a right of residence in these countries who have no symptoms of the disease, may enter Estonia without an obligation for quarantine. 

-Finnish citizens, holders of residence permits or persons with a right of residence in Finland, who have no symptoms of the disease, who come to Estonia to work, study or for unavoidable family reasons such as meeting with their close relatives, attending a funeral or a wedding, or need to visit due to a case of illness, can also enter Estonia.

-A foreign national without any symptoms of the disease, traveling to their home country is also allowed to transit through Estonia.

-People without symptoms of the disease, who have had the right to enter Estonia previously without an obligation to stay in quarantine, may continue to do so.

description: Starting from July 6, 2020, by order of the Estonian Ministry of Health, upon arrival from countries outside the European Union, where the number of infections per 100,000 people exceeds 16, persons entering Estonia for the purpose of work or study must remain in isolation. It is necessary to provide both transport and accommodation during the 14-day self-isolation period, as well as two tests for coronavirus, one of which is carried out upon arrival in Estonia, and the other on the 14th day of stay. An employee can start working in Estonia on the 15th day of their stay in Estonia if the second test is negative.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, June 12, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who are allowed to enter Estonia at the state border need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. There are various exceptions for asymptomatic persons.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From July 6, 2020, there are additional exceptions as per section 1-2, numbers 7 to 10, section 1-3 and section 1-4 of the (new) source document.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Estonia, July 13, 2020:
As per SchengenVisaInfo.com, the Estonian Ministry of Interior declares that travellers from Sweden, Portugal, Romania, Bulgaria, Croatia, the Czech Republic and Luxembourg have to self-isolate for two weeks after entering Estonia. Additionally, arrivals from Montenegro and Serbia have to quarantine if they come from countries other than the approved 14 countries. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 16 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until July 19, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)
enforcer: National Government,Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
Estonia, July 16, 2020:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 and those permanently residing with them are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until the recovery of the diagnosed person, which is decided by a physician. There are various exceptions such as if there is an order to leave one's quarantine location.
This policy is slated to end on September 30, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Asylum/refugee seekers,Homeless population,Other population not specifed above
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
Stenbock House, 16 July 2020 â the Estonian government renewed the quarantine requirements applicable to people diagnosed with COVID-19 and people living with them or permanently staying in the same place of residence, with a new term of 30 September 2020. As previously, people diagnosed with COVID-19 are forbidden from leaving their place of residence or permanent place of stay until their illness has ended, except at the order of a healthcare worker or police officer or in an emergency endangering the personâs life or health.
The place of provision of a shelter or safe house service is also considered a place of residence or permanent place of stay.
People in close contact with the infected person who live with them or are permanently staying in the same place of residence may leave their place of residence only on limited occasions if they have no symptoms of illness and if they are a healthcare worker or a person performing public duties carrying out their work assignments if they monitor their health carefully and abide by the measures established by the government or Health Board to prevent the possible spread of the infectious disease. ...people in close contact with the infected person may leave their home to acquire things required for everyday life and to spend time outside, provided that they take all measures to prevent the possible spread of the infectious disease, as well as if any contact with a person diagnosed with COVID is prevented.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Estonia, July 27, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Austria, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, San Marino, Slovakia, Slovenia, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, and the Vatican City, as well as, as for third countries, Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, South Korea, Rwanda, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 16 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until August 2, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, August 31, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Finland, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Norway, San Marino, Slovakia, Vatican, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 16 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until September 6, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On the 28th of September the Estonian government's policy stating that If the infection rate is above 25 / 100 000 inhabitants in Finland, Latvia and Lithuania, the travellers from the country in question are required to quarantine for 14 days was amended so that Latvia, Lithuania and Finland are exempt from self-isolation in certain cases if the infection rate of these countries rises above 25. People arriving in Estonia from these countries are not required to self-isolate for two weeks if they are coming here to work, study, access healthcare services, attend a family event or for the purposes of transit, and they exhibit no symptoms or have had no known contact with an infected person. UPDATE: The original policy set that if the number of infections in Finland, Latvia or Lithuania was over 25 per 100 000 inhabitants, all travellers from these countries were required to quarantine for 14 days. Now the rules have been relaxed so that the traveller can be exempted from the 14 day self-isolation under certain circumstances. These include if they are coming to Estonia to work, study, access healthcare services, attend a family event or for the purposes of transit, and they exhibit no symptoms or have had no known contact with an infected person.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:

UPDATE: From September 28, 2020, if the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus per 100,000 inhabitants for the past 14 days is greater than 25 in Lithuania, Latvia or Finland, individuals may be exempted from quarantine rules if they arrive from these countries for the purpose of working, studying or receiving health services or for family reasons or transit (previously, there were no exemptions above the threshold of 25).

description:
Estonia, September 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From October 12, 2020, the infection rate threshold for European countries, starting from which people arriving from there will be subject to a self-quarantine period of 14 days, is raised to 50. If this number is greater than 50 for Lithuania, Latvia or Finland, only those arriving for the purpose of working, studying or receiving health services or for family reasons or transit may be exempted. There are now also exceptions for Valga/Valka residents.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
Estonia, September 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From October 19, 2020, if the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus per 100,000 inhabitants for the past 14 days in Lithuania, Latvia or Finland is over 10% greater than the number for Estonia or greater than 50, individuals may be exempted from quarantine rules if they submit a negative test result taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in the country. Those who arrive for the purpose of working, studying or receiving health services or for family reasons or transit may take a test after arrival in Estonia and must stay in their place of residence or permanent place of stay until finding out that their test was negative.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Estonia, October 30, 2020:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 14 days after the last close contact. There are various exceptions such as if there is an order to leave one's quarantine location. Contact persons may stop quarantining after 10 days by means of a negative test result, if certified by a physician as being free of infection or if so decided by authorities.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, August 19, 2020:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 and those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with them are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until the recovery of the diagnosed persony, which is decided by a physician. There are various exceptions such as if there is an order to leave one's quarantine location.
This policy is slated to end on September 30, 2020. UPDATE: From October 30, 2020, contact persons of diagnosed individuals may stop quarantining 14 calendar days after the last close contact.

description:
Estonia, November 2, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Finland, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, South Korea, Thailand, Singapur. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 50 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until November 8, 2020.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, December 28, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Iceland, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 50 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.

description:
Estonia, December 28, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From January 15, 2021, the quarantine period is reduced to 10 days. Also, quarantine may now be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. Compliance with the policy is eased as per sections 3 and 4 of the (new) source document. Among other things, the infection rate threshold for the UK, starting from which people arriving from there will be subject to a self-quarantine period of 10 days, is raised to 150.

description:
Estonia, September 1, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 14 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results (one upon arrival and the other on the 7th day of quarantine). There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From January 15, 2021, quarantine may already be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. Also, the infection rate threshold for European countries as per section 4, number 10 of the (new) source document, starting from which people arriving from there will be subject to a self-quarantine period of 10 days, is raised to 150. If the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus per 100,000 inhabitants for the past 14 days in Lithuania, Latvia or Finland is greater than 150, individuals from there may be exempted from quarantine rules if they submit a negative test result taken promptly after arrival in the country. Until the test has come back negative the person is required to remain in their place of residence or permanent place of stay.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: All countries

UPDATE: From January 15, 2021, quarantine may already be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. Also, the infection rate threshold for European countries as per section 4, number 10 of the (new) source document, starting from which people arriving from there will be subject to a self-quarantine period of 10 days, is raised to 150. If the cumulative number of positive tests for the coronavirus per 100,000 inhabitants for the past 14 days in Lithuania, Latvia or Finland is greater than 150, individuals from there may be exempted from quarantine rules if they submit a negative test result taken promptly after arrival in the country. Until the test has come back negative the person is required to remain in their place of residence or permanent place of stay.

Estonia, December 28, 2020:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Iceland, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, New Zealand, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand and Uruguay. description:
Estonia, February 1, 2021:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 10 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions such as for recovered and/or vaccinated persons.
This policy (the exemptions for recovered/vaccinated persons and section 8 of the source document; see section 20-12) only applies to Harju County and Ida-Viru County. It is in place until February 2 when all other counties (again) have to follow identical quarantine rules.

description:
Estonia, February 2, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on May 31, 2021.

description:
Estonia, January 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 14 days. There are various exceptions such as if there is an order to leave one's quarantine location. Contact persons may stop quarantining after 10 days by means of a negative test result (for more details, see section 5 of the source document).
This policy is slated to end on February 1, 2021. UPDATE: From February 2, 2021, there is no longer the possibility of shortening the quarantine period to 10 days by means of a negative test result.

description:
Estonia, December 28, 2020:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 10 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy applies to all countries except for the UK (the UK is treated separately). It is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From February 3, 2021, recovered and vaccinated persons are also exempted from quarantine rules. Those in the context of public events/sports competitions (artists, athletes etc.) do no longer have to explicitly be asymptomatic in order to be exempted from quarantine rules.
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Estonia, March 15, 2021:
The list of risk countries for which quarantine requirements apply is updated. Now, a two-week restriction on freedom of movement will apply to people arriving in Estonia from all countries except, as for European countries, Denmark, Germany, Iceland, Norway, Portugal, Spain, as well as, as for third countries, Australia, New Zealand, South Korea, Rwanda, Singapore, Thailand. According to the regulations imposed by the Estonian government, citizens from European countries where the ratio of coronavirus infections is greater than 150 cases for 100,000 people are obliged to follow quarantine requirements. For third countries, recommendations of the Council of the European Union are followed. There are exceptions.
The current list of countries subject to mandatory self-isolation is valid until March 21, 2021.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Quarantine may be ended after 7 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.

description:
Estonia, April 5, 2021:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 10 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From May 3, 2021, there are additional exceptions for asymptomatic persons "who cross the state border between the Republic of Estonia and the Republic of Latvia at least twice a week for the purpose of urgent cross-border work or studies, provided the relevant person has taken at least one test for the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 causing COVID-19 during the past seven days and the results of that test have come back negative or a physician has declared the person not to be contagious".
date_end_spec: The policyâs end date is unknown or unreported

description:
Estonia, February 2, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that persons diagnosed with COVID-19 are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on May 31, 2021. UPDATE: From May 22, 2021, there are additional exceptions for contact persons participating in the European Golden League - Men volleyball tournament.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, April 5, 2021:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 10 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. Quarantine may be ended after 6 days by means of two negative test results. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. Exceptions now also apply to a person who has contracted COVID-19 after the first dose of vaccine and no more than one year has passed since the person was declared healthy by a physician (they are considered a "recovered person" if having contracted COVID-19 within two weeks after the first dose of vaccine).

description:
Estonia, June 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that infected persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2021. UPDATE: From July 19, 2021, a person is considered recovered if "no more than 180 days have passed since the SARS-CoV-2 test confirming the diagnosis was carried out or since the date of confirmation of the diagnosis" (previously, if "no more than six months have passed since the person was declared healthy"). The date of the SARS-CoV-2 test is now also decisive for those who may be a "person considered equal to a vaccinated person" (and not the date a person was declared healthy by a physician, as was previously the case).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2021. UPDATE: From September 1, 2021, there are additional exceptions for contact persons who are children and juveniles up to 18 years of age as per section 4, numbers 9 and 10 of the source document.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
Estonia, June 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that infected persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. There are various exceptions such as for contact persons who have recovered from or have been vaccinated against the coronavirus.
This policy is slated to end on December 31, 2021. UPDATE: From February 1, 2022, contact persons are considered fully vaccinated and therefore exempted from quarantine rules if they have completed their vaccination series for COVID-19, have developed full protection after the last dose of a vaccine and no more than 270 days have passed (previously, it was one year) since the last dose of vaccine. Also, contact persons are now considered equal to a vaccinated person (and therefore also exempted from quarantine rules) if they have been given one dose of a vaccine after recovering from COVID-19 and have developed full protection after the dose and no more than 270 days have passed since (previously, it was also one year).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
target_who_gen: Asylum/refugee seekers,Homeless population,People who are neither vaccinated nor recovered from COVID-19

description:
Estonia, January 10, 2022:
The National Government declares that persons who have crossed the state border for the purpose of entering Estonia need to go into quarantine for 7 days at their the place of residence or permanent place of stay. There are various exceptions.
The policy is in place until further notice. The need for it shall be assessed no later than after every two weeks. UPDATE: From February 1, 2022, persons are exempted from the obligation to quarantine if they "ha[ve] completed the vaccination series for COVID-19, ha[ve] developed full protection after the last dose of vaccine and no more than 270 days have passed since the last dose of vaccine" (previously, it was one year). Also, persons are now considered equal to a vaccinated person if, among other things, "no more than 270 days have passed since the last dose of vaccine, or [...] no more than 270 days have passed since the SARS-CoV-2 test confirming the diagnosis was carried out or since the date of confirmation of the diagnosis" (previously, it was also one year).

description:
Estonia, June 1, 2021:
The Estonian National Government declares that infected persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided until their recovery, which is decided by a physician. Those who are permanently residing or have been in close contact with diagnosed persons are prohibited from leaving their place of residence, permanent place of stay or place where shelter services and safe house services are provided for 10 days. description: The majority of shops will close and new movement restrictions will be introduced in Saaremaa and Muhu in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) Prime Minister JÃ¼ri Ratas announced late on Saturday night. On Saturday, Ratas (Center) signed an amendment which will see most of the stores and close contact service providers close their doors from Sunday (March 29) in the municipalities of Saaremaa and Muhu.Starting Sunday, March 29:Grocery stores, pharmacies, telecommunications stores, bank offices, parcel terminals, post offices, stores where technical aids and medical devices are sold or rented, and optician's stores may remain open in the municipalities of Saaremaa and Muhu.Construction stores may remain open for sales through a window or from the storeroom. The store's sales area must be closed.Gardening shops may also remain open.All other stores and markets must be closed to customers.All eateries must be closed for on-site eating, takeaway and delivery service for taking food home are allowed.All services that require close contact must be closed â cosmetic surgery services, beauty and personal services (for instance hairdressing, manicure, pedicure, beautician, tattooing and solarium services), and massage and other rehabilitation services as wellness services.Libraries are closed to visitors.The restriction does not include employees and owners, so e-commerce can continue.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: The majority of shops will close and new movement restrictions will be introduced in Saaremaa and Muhu in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) Prime Minister JÃ¼ri Ratas announced late on Saturday night. On Saturday, Ratas (Center) signed an amendment which will see most of the stores and close contact service providers close their doors from Sunday (March 29) in the municipalities of Saaremaa and Muhu.Starting Sunday, March 29:Grocery stores, pharmacies, telecommunications stores, bank offices, parcel terminals, post offices, stores where technical aids and medical devices are sold or rented, and optician's stores may remain open in the municipalities of Saaremaa and Muhu.Construction stores may remain open for sales through a window or from the storeroom. The store's sales area must be closed.Gardening shops may also remain open.All other stores and markets must be closed to customers.All eateries must be closed for on-site eating, takeaway and delivery service for taking food home are allowed.All services that require close contact must be closed â cosmetic surgery services, beauty and personal services (for instance hairdressing, manicure, pedicure, beautician, tattooing and solarium services), and massage and other rehabilitation services as wellness services.Libraries are closed to visitors.The restriction does not include employees and owners, so e-commerce can continue.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_cat: No information in the policy about whether the business is considered essential or non-essential
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Other condition not specified above (please provide detail in the text entry)

description: In order to prevent further spread of the virus, on April 1, the Estonian Ministry of Health established a rule on the availability of disinfectants in the trading floor or service room.  The order changes the requirement for the placement of disinfectant, which currently must be located at the entrance to a store or service hall.  From now on, the store owner can place it in the place where the disinfectant is most needed.  It is important that customers are clearly informed of where the disinfectant is located.  Otherwise, the customer must not enter the store.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
institution_cat: Non-Essential Businesses
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Hygiene and sanitation measures required
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On April 3, 2020, Estonia's government announces that from April 4, 2020 stores are required to calculate the maximum number of customers that fit in their premises while following the distancing requirements. Stores must monitor and limit store occupancy based on these calculations. Shops, post offices, pharmacies and service providers must also ensure that people waiting behind the door follow the rule and that there are no queues where people stand together more closely. According to the rule, stores should preferably be visited alone or in pairs, keeping a distance of at least 2 meters from other customers.

description: On May 5 2020, Estonia's government announces that from May 5, 2020 driving schools are allowed to conduct driving lessons for drivers of motorised vehicles and cars, and transporters of dangerous goods, if they comply with the special requirements.Pursuant to the special requirements, only an instructor and a student without symptoms of the COVID-19 infection are allowed to participate in driving lessons. Disinfectants must be available in every vehicle. Organisers of driving lessons must clean all surfaces that a student touched after each lesson. Students and instructors may wear personal protective equipment of individual preference, for example, a protective mask or a visor.

August 2020 - 0:00The police will also continue to restrict late-night alcohol sales in Tartu County.Vallo Koppel, Prefect of the South Prefecture, said that new students will arrive to Tartu for the new school year from very different areas (including from abroad), but since the epidemiological situation has worsened, we cannot ease the restriction on late-night alcohol sales in Tartumaa which was introduced on 7 August. description: 28. August 2020 - 0:00As of tomorrow, 29. August, the police will restrict late-night alcohol sales in Harjumaa. By order of the head of the North prefecture, retail sale of alcoholic beverages will be restricted in Harju County from 11 p.m. to 6 a.m. The restriction will remain in force until further notice, but it is currently estimated to be a short-term restriction, the duration of which depends on the attitude and behaviour of people and their compliance with the requirement of dispersion. The Police and Border Guard Board and the Health Board will re-evaluate the relevance of the restriction once a week.âAccording to the Health Board, in Estonia, the risk for the spread of the infection is the highest in Tallinn due to large population and high population density. As of this morning, there are 61 active cases in Harju County, and the Health Board estimates that some of the infected persons contracted the virus directly or indirectly at an entertainment facility where it is common to consume alcoholic beverages.

description:
New movement restrictions will be introduced in Estonia in the Saaremaa and Muhu municipalities in an effort to contain the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) and limit the burden on the health system. Stricter restrictions on movement will go into force on Monday March 30 2020.  A general 2+2 rule applies to moving around outside, according to which only 2 people can be in a public space together and a 2 metre distance must be kept from others.
If a person does not stick to the new measures the police will issue a warning. The next sanction used will be a penalty payment of up to â¬2,000.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On April 3, 2020, Estonia's government announces that from April 4, 2020 stores are required to calculate the maximum number of customers that fit in their premises while following the distancing requirements. Stores must monitor and limit store occupancy based on these calculations. Shops, post offices, pharmacies and service providers must also ensure that people waiting behind the door follow the rule and that there are no queues where people stand together more closely. According to the rule, stores should preferably be visited alone or in pairs, keeping a distance of at least 2 meters from other customers.

Disinfectants must be available in every vehicle. Organisers of driving lessons must clean all surfaces that a student touched after each lesson. description:
As of 17th May 2020, Estonia follows the 2+2 rule:
In public places and indoor premises, the so-called 2+2 rule remains in force, which means that both outdoors and indoors up to two people may be together, keeping a distance of 2-meters from other people. The rule does not apply to families or at homes. The rule applies to all activities in Estonia that do not take place in domestic conditions.

description:
As of 17th May 2020, Estonia follows the 2+2 rule:
In public places and indoor premises, the so-called 2+2 rule remains in force, which means that both outdoors and indoors up to two people may be together, keeping a distance of 2-meters from other people. The rule does not apply to families or at homes. The rule applies to all activities in Estonia that do not take place in domestic conditions. UPDATE: With effect from 19 June 2020, the Government of the Republic decided to replace the 2+2 rule with a requirement for people to disperse. This means that a safe distance between people must continue to be maintained, but the state no longer requires compliance with the 2+2 rule, as Estonian residents understand and accept the need to keep their distance.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: With effect from 19 2020 June, the Government of the Republic decided to replace the 2+2 rule with a requirement for people to disperse. This means that a safe distance between people must continue to be maintained, but the state no longer requires compliance with the 2+2 rule, as Estonian residents understand and accept the need to keep their distance. The requirement will apply in public saunas, spas, swimming pools and water parks as well as bowling alleys, billiard rooms and children's playrooms. It will also apply in basic schools, upper secondary schools, vocational education institutions and higher education institutions, as well as in organising the activities of continuing education institutions, hobby schools and open youth centres. It will also extend to youth camps and student camps, sports activities and visits to museums and exhibitions.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
